etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin mitigat- ‘softened, alleviated’, from the verb mitigare, from mitis ‘mild’

notes.text: The verbs mitigate and militate have a similarity in form but are quite different in meaning. Mitigate means ‘make (something bad) less severe,’ (he wanted to mitigate misery in the world), while militate is nearly always used in constructions with against to mean ‘be a powerful factor in preventing’ (laws that militate against personal freedoms)

definitions: make less severe, serious, or painful

examples.text: he wanted to mitigate misery in the world

shortDefinitions: make something bad less severe or painful

definitions: lessen the gravity of (an offense or mistake)

examples.text: there had been a provocation that mitigated the offense to a degree
